children.name: to love sb especially in a sexual or romantic way
love
children.definition: to have a strong feeling of liking someone, caring about them, and being sexually attracted to them:

children.name: ▪ He stroked her hair and murmured, ‘I love you.’
examples: ▪ He was the only man she had ever loved.

children.name: love somebody very much
examples: ▪ We still love each other very much.

children.name: be in love
children.definition: to love someone very much, so that you think about them all the time and want to be with them all the time:
examples: ▪ I think I’m in love!

children.name: be in love with
examples: ▪ How can you marry Adam when you’re in love with someone else?

children.name: be madly in love/very much in lovevery strongly in love
examples: ▪ We were both seventeen and madly in love.

children.name: be crazy about
children.definition: to love someone very much, especially in a way that youcannotcontrol:
examples: ▪ Jo’s crazy about you

children.name: fancy
children.definition: spokento be sexually attracted to someone, especially someone that youdo not know very well:

children.name: mến
examples: ▪ All the girls fancy Bob.
▪ I think Stevie fancies you.

children.name: have a crush on
children.definition: if someone, especially a young person, has a crush on someone they have an uncontrollable feeling of love for them, especially when there is no chance of having a relationship with them:
examples: ▪ It is quite normal for adolescents to have crushes on pop stars.
▪ The only reason I went to church every Sunday was that I had a crush on the minister.

children.name: be besotted
children.definition: to be so much in love with someone that you do not behave sensibly or think clearly:
examples: ▪ She was too besotted to see what he was really like.

children.name: be besotted with
examples: ▪ He was obviously besotted with Julia.

children.name: be infatuated
children.definition: to have a strong and uncontrollable feeling of love for someone you do not know very well, which does not last for a long time:
examples: ▪ Ever since she met Rod at a party she’s been totally infatuated.
infatuation/ɪnˌfætʃuˈeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]
▪ I thought I was in love with Darren, but it was just infatuation.

children.name: be infatuated with
examples: ▪ Teenage girls sometimes become infatuated with their teachers.

children.name: love
children.definition: a feeling of love, either for someone that you are sexually attracted to, or for a member of your family:

children.name: tình yêu
examples: ▪ All children need love, attention, and encouragement.

children.name: love for
examples: ▪ She was never able to express her love for Henry.

children.name: unrequited loveromantic love that you feel for someone, but that they do not feel for you : tình yêu đơn phương
examples: ▪ She nourishes a secret, unrequited love for Harry.

children.name: affection
children.definition: a gentle feeling of love for afriendormemberof your family, which makes you want to be kind to them and show them that you love them:
examples: sự yêu mếm
▪ She never seemed to show us any affection.
▪ children who have been starved of affection
affection for
▪ Alison and I had been at school together, and I felt great affection for her.

children.name: devotion
children.definition: a strong feeling of loving and being loyal to someone, especially over a long period of time:
examples: ▪ She had given her husband years of devotion and support.
▪ Mary expected complete devotion from her lovers.

children.name: passion
children.definition: a strong and exciting feeling of love for someone you are extremely sexually attracted to:
examples: ▪ All the passion in their marriage has died.
▪ He loved her still, with just the same passion as he always had.

children.name: infatuation
children.definition: unreasonably strong feelings of love that you have for only a short time, especially for someone that you do not know very well:
examples: ▪ She hoped that his ridiculous infatuation would soon wear off.

children.name: infatuation with/for
examples: ▪ His infatuation with Diane seemed to be growing.

children.name: affectionate
children.definition: someone who is affectionate shows that they are very fond of another person by the way they behave towards them, for example by holding or kissing them:
examples: trìu mến , tình cảm,
▪ She’s a very affectionate child.

children.name: ▪ He gave me an affectionate hug and then lef
romantic
children.definition: something that is romantic gives you a feeling of love for your boyfriend, girlfriend, husband, wife etc - use this aboutplaces, orthingspeople do or say:

children.name: lãng mạn
examples: ▪ We went for a lovely romantic walk by the lake.
▪ Paris is such a romantic city.
▪ I’ve always thought it would be so romantic to be serenaded.

children.name: loving
children.definition: behaving in a way that shows that you love someone, especially a member of your family:
examples: ▪ Her husband was loving and supportive throughout her long illness.
▪ She was a devoted wife and a very loving mother.

children.name: passionate
children.definition: involving strong feelings of sexual love:
examples: ▪ She longed to have a mad, passionate affair with him.
▪ As they got to know each other better, their love grew deeper and more passionate.

children.name: tender
children.definition: loving and gentle, especially because you are concerned about someone:
examples: ▪ When she spoke, her voice was full of tender concern.
▪ Fleury saw an expression of tender devotion come over his father’s face.
tenderness[uncountable noun]
▪ He looked after his wife with infinite care and tenderness.

children.name: tender loving care
examples: ▪ I was feeling rather fragile, and in need of tender loving care.

children.name: lovesick
children.definition: spending all your time thinking about someone you love, especially someone who does not love you:
examples: ▪ He knew he was behaving like a lovesick teenager.

children.name: devoted
children.definition: very loving and loyal towards someone:
examples: ▪ With the support of his devoted wife, he carried on writing until the age of 73.
▪ They remained devoted friends for many years.

children.name: doting mother/grandparent/husband etc a mother, grandparent etc
examples: that shows that they love someone, especially someone younger, by paying them a lot of attention:
▪ The doting grandmother smiled and chatted about how well the boy was doing at school.
▪ She managed to find a rich and doting husband for herself.

children.name: lovey-dovey/gooey
children.definition: expressing your love for someone in a way that other people think is silly:
examples: ▪ It is possible to love someone without going all gooey over them.
▪ We ended up sitting next to a lovey-dovey couple.

children.name: romance story
children.definition: romance/love story  a story about two people who are in love with each other:

children.name: chuyện tình
examples: ▪ The book is very exciting, as well as being a wonderful love story.

children.name: ▪ a well-known writer of popular romances
romantic
children.definition: a romantic story or film is about people who are in love:
examples: ( chuyện tình ) lãng mạn
▪ a romantic comedy in which Meg Ryan plays a single mother looking for love

children.name: fall in love
children.definition: tobeginto be in love with someone:
examples: ▪ I suddenly realized that I’d fallen in love.

children.name: fall in love with
examples: ▪ I think I fell in love with Ralph the first time I met him.

children.name: fall/be head-over-heels (in love)
children.definition: to suddenly start to love someone a lot:
examples: ▪ I met Sam at college, and immediately fell head-over-heels in love with him.
▪ I was head-over-heels in love with someone who barely even noticed me.

children.name: fall for
children.definition: to start to love someone:
examples: ▪ She always seems to fall for the wrong type of man.
▪ I fell for Dan almost immediately.

children.name: love at first sight
children.definition: a situation in which you start to love someone the first time you see them:
examples: ▪ When I met Tracy it was love at first sight.
▪ I don’t believe in love at first sight.

children.name: sweep somebody off their feet
children.definition: if someone sweeps you off your feet, you start to love them very quickly, especially when you do not expect it to happen:
examples: ▪ Then Peter came into my life and swept me off my feet.
▪ She’s just waiting to be swept off her feet by a handsome stranger.

children.name: to like sb a lot and care about them
love
children.definition: to love someone in your family, so that you care a lot about what happens to them, and you want them to be happy:
examples: ▪ I really believed that my parents didn’t love me.
▪ He loved his stepdaughter as if she were his own child.

children.name: close
children.definition: if people are close, they enjoy being together and they know and understand each other’s feelings and thoughts:
examples: ▪ My sister and I used to argue a lot, but now we’re very close.
▪ We have always been a close family.

children.name: close to
examples: ▪ I’m still very close to my parents.

children.name: adore
children.definition: to love someone very much and feel proud of them:
examples: ▪ Branwell Bronte adored his sister Anne.
▪ She adores her grandchildren and is always buying them presents.

children.name: be fond of
children.definition: to like someone very much, especially after spending a long time with them and getting to know them:
examples: ▪ I’m very fond of my sister’s children.
▪ All teachers have children that they are particularly fond of.
▪ We were all very fond of Mr Edwards.

children.name: care
children.definition: to feel love and concern for someone:
examples: ▪ She thinks we’re interfering but we’re only doing it because we care.
▪ Buy her some flowers to show her you really care.

children.name: care about
examples: ▪ I’m very lucky to have a husband, family and friends who care about me.
▪ Of course I care about Kirsty - that’s why I want to help her.

children.name: worship
children.definition: to love and admire someone very much:
examples: ▪ He worshipped his elder brother.
worship the ground somebody walks on
love someone very much, even if they behave badly
▪ In Susie’s eyes he can do no wrong - she worships the ground he walks on.

children.name: be devoted to
children.definition: to love someone very much and be very loyal to them or spend all your time with them:
examples: ▪ He is a good man, devoted to his wife and children.

children.name: dote on
children.definition: to love someone, especially someone younger than you, very much and show this by your actions:
examples: ▪ He’d do anything for his children - he really dotes on them.
▪ She obviously dotes on her grandson.
▪ You should visit your aunt more often, you know how she dotes on you all.

children.name: think the world of
children.definition: to love and respect someone so much that they are very important in your life:
examples: ▪ We all thought the world of Isaac and were devastated when he died.
▪ He thinks the world of his uncle.

children.name: unloved
children.definition: not loved by someone or anyone:
examples: ▪ As a child I felt very unloved.
▪ He was the unloved son of an unhappy marriage.
